channel.title: Homes on Alan Mishler
channel.description: Recent content in Homes on Alan Mishler

item.description: About I am a PhD student in the Department of Statistics & Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University, entering my third year. I work with Professor Rebecca Nugent on clustering methods to estimate latent class parameters in cognitive diagnosis models, and I work with Professor Edward Kennedy on counterfactual formulations of fairness criteria in the context of algorithmic bias. I am also currently a Data Scientist/Quantitative Analyst Intern at Google in New York City, working on a text processing component of a machine learning pipeline.

item.title: News & Events
item.description: 07/2018: Presentation at the Doctoral Consortium at the Educational Data Mining conference in Buffalo, NY. 06/2018—08/2018: Data Scientist internship at Google in New York City. 06/2018: Poster presentation at the Classification Society Meeting in Stony Brook NY. 05/2018: Poster presentation at the Atlantic Causal Inference Conference in Pittsburgh, PA. 11/2017: Competing with the same group (below) as a national finalist at the Citadel Datathon in New York, NY.

item.title: Research
item.description: Parameter estimation in cognitive diagnosis models using clustering Project with Rebecca Nugent Cognitive Diagnosis Models (CDMs) are a type of latent class model used frequently in education and psychometrics. One typical application is to estimate whether students in a learning environment have mastered or not mastered each of a set of K skills. Traditional likelihood-based estimation methods are computationally intensive and become intractable for large datasets. We are investigating how to optimally estimate skill profiles using a lightweight, model-agnostic alternative: clustering, via k-means type algorithms or hierarchical agglomerative clustering.
